Package graph

Interface Graph

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    TSPGraph, UndirectedGraph
    public interface Graph
    A graph is a set of vertices (sometimes referred to as nodes) interconnected by edges. These vertices and edges are mathematical abstractions, that is, these can be anything. In contrast to other data structures such as a List or a Set, which consist on a collection of nodes that are connected to one another, one node can only point to the previous or the following node. On the other hand, a graph establishes the concept of network between various nodes.

    The Graph interface provides the fundamental functions that are needed when employing a generic weighted graph as a data structure, that is to all edges a numeric weight is assigned. Usually, this weight is a positive integer number and, as such, this interface associates all edges a positive weight. Moreover, edges which connect a vertex to itself are not allowed.

    Another aspect to be considered is that all vertices, independently of their content, are identified by an integer number, an ID. In this manner, operations as finding a node, accessing, adding or removing edges are fairly simplified. The assignment of this ID should be unique for each node, as a graph contains no duplicates vertices.

    Before implementing this interface, the core elements of a graph, which are vertices and edges, must be defined. In this manner, the service provided by the interfaces Vertex and Edge must be implemented, as the methods provided by the Graph rely on the implementation of the before mentioned interfaces.

    In summary, the Graph interface provides methods for:

    • Adding a new vertex to the graph or remove a vertex given an ID.
    • Adding or removing edges given the IDs of two existing nodes. Notice that in order to implement a directed graph, the Vertex and Edge interfaces should be implemented accordingly.
    • Getting and setting the weight of a specific edge given two vertex IDs.
    • Getting the edge that links to vertices identified by their IDs.
    • Getting a vertex with a specified ID.
    • Obtaining all edges touching the a certain vertex.
    • Retrieving all vertices in the graph.
    See Also:
    Vertex, Edge

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field Description
      static int DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT
      Whenever an edge is added without specifying its weight, the default value is defined by this constant.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT

        static final int DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT
        Whenever an edge is added without specifying its weight, the default value is defined by this constant.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getSize

        int getSize()
        Returns the total number of vertices in the graph.
        Returns:
        the number of vertices in the graph

      • findVertex

        Vertex findVertex​(int id)
           throws VertexNotFound
        Given the identifier of a vertex, such vertex is returned from a collection of all nodes belonging to the graph. If the vertex with such ID does not exist, an exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        id - the identifier of the vertex to be found and returned.
        Returns:
        the vertex with the specified identifier
        Throws:
        VertexNotFound - if the specified ID does not correspond to any vertex belonging to the graph

      • addEdge

        boolean addEdge​(int id1,
                int id2)
         throws SameVertex
        Adds an edge between two vertices.

        It should be noticed that it is not allowed to have multiple edges connecting the same two nodes. Hence, before adding the new edge, it is verified whether the new edge already exists.

        Should the graph to be implemented to be directed, the order of the IDs given as parameters for this function must be fixed. Additionally, the implementation of Vertex should be done accordingly.

        Furthermore, as the weight of the edge is not specified, the weight of the new edge is equal to Graph.DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT.

        Finally, no edge can be added between one vertex and itself.

        Parameters:
        id1 - the identifier of the first vertex.
        id2 - the identifier of the second vertex.
        Returns:
        true if the an edge between two vertices specified by the two IDs is inserted successfully.
        Throws:
        SameVertex - if the new edge is to be inserted connecting a vertex to itself

      • addEdge

        boolean addEdge​(int id1,
                int id2,
                int weight)
         throws SameVertex
        Adds an edge between two vertices.

        It should be noticed that it is not allowed to have multiple edges connecting the same two nodes. Hence, before adding the new edge, it is verified whether the new edge already exists.

        Should the graph to be implemented to be directed, the order of the IDs given as parameters for this function must be fixed. Additionally, the implementation of Vertex should be done accordingly.

        Furthermore, the weight of new edge needs to be specified. This weight must be greater or equal to 1.

        Finally, no edge can be added between one vertex and itself.

        Parameters:
        id1 - the identifier of the first vertex.
        id2 - the identifier of the second vertex.
        weight - the weight of the edge to be inserted between the two vertices.
        Returns:
        true if the an edge between two vertices specified by the two IDs is inserted successfully.
        Throws:
        SameVertex - if the new edge is to be inserted connecting a vertex to itself

      • addVertex

        void addVertex()
        Adds a new vertex to the graph. The assignment of the ID of this new vertex should be handled by the implementation of Vertex. The ID assigned to the new vertex should be the next number following the ID of the last node inserted.

      • findEdge

        Edge findEdge​(int id1,
              int id2)
       throws EdgeNotFound,
              SameVertex,
              VertexNotFound
        Returns the edge connecting the vertices indexed by the IDs.

        Should the graph to be implemented to be directed, the order of the IDs given as parameters for this function must be fixed.

        Parameters:
        id1 - the identifier of the first vertex.
        id2 - the identifier of the second vertex.
        Returns:
        true if an edge between the two specified vertices exists
        Throws:
        EdgeNotFound - if there is no edge linking the two vertices
        SameVertex - if the new edge is to be inserted connecting a vertex to itself
        VertexNotFound - if one of the vertices does not exist

      • degreeOf

        int degreeOf​(int id)
        Returns the number of edge touching the vertex with the specified ID. (the degree of the vertex).

        The distinction of inward or outward edges is not done.

        The implementation of this method may require the implemented methods of Vertex Edge interfaces.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex of which the degree is to be returned.
        Returns:
        the number of edges touching the specified vertex

      • degreeOfInward

        int degreeOfInward​(int id)
        Returns the number of inward edges of the specified vertex. In other words, returns the count of edges directed to vertex with such ID.

        The implementation of this method may require the implemented methods of Vertex Edge interfaces.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex of which the number of inward edges is to be determined.
        Returns:
        the number of edges incoming to the specified vertex

      • degreeOfOutward

        int degreeOfOutward​(int id)
        Returns the number of outward edges of the specified vertex. In other words, returns the count of edges which begin at the vertex with such ID.

        The implementation of this method may require the implemented methods of Vertex Edge interfaces.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex of which the number of outward edges is to be determined.
        Returns:
        the number of edges leaving from the specified vertex

      • getAllEdges

        Edge[] getAllEdges​(int id)
        Returns an array containing all edges connected to the specified node.

        The distinction of inward or outward edges is not done.

        The implementation of this method may require the implemented methods of Vertex and Edge interfaces.

        If the vertex is disconnected from all other, an empty array is returned.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex of which all edges linked to which are returned.
        Returns:
        an array containing all edges connected to the specified node

      • getInwardEdges

        Edge[] getInwardEdges​(int id)
        Returns an array containing all edges inward connected to the specified node.

        The implementation of this method may require the implemented methods of Vertex Edge interfaces.

        If the vertex contains no edges directed to itself, an empty array is returned.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex of which all inward are returned.
        Returns:
        an array containing all inward edges connected to the specified node

      • getOutwardEdges

        Edge[] getOutwardEdges​(int id)
        Returns an array containing all edges departing from the specified node.

        The implementation of this method may require the implemented methods of Vertex Edge interfaces.

        If the vertex contains no edges pointing to other vertices, an empty array is returned.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex of which all outward are returned.
        Returns:
        an array containing all outward edges connected to the specified node

      • getEdgeWeight

        int getEdgeWeight​(int id1,
                  int id2)
        Returns the weight of the edge linking the two specified nodes.

        Should the graph to be implemented to be directed, the order of the IDs given as parameters for this function must be fixed. Additionally, the implementation of Vertex should be done accordingly.

        Parameters:
        id1 - the identifier of the first vertex.
        id2 - the identifier of the second vertex.
        Returns:
        0 if the edge between the two specified nodes does not exist

      • removeEdge

        boolean removeEdge​(int id1,
                   int id2)
        Removes an edge between the two specified vertices.

        In this case, before removing the an edge, it is verified whether the this edge does indeed exist. Should this edge be inexistent and false is returned.

        Should the graph to be implemented to be directed, the order of the IDs given as parameters for this function must be fixed. Additionally, the implementation of Vertex should be done accordingly.

        Parameters:
        id1 - the identifier of the first vertex.
        id2 - the identifier of the second vertex.
        Returns:
        true if the specified edge is successfully removed.

      • removeVertex

        boolean removeVertex​(int id)
        Removes the specified vertex from the graph. Additionally, all inward or outward edges connected to this vertex are also deleted.

        If the vertex labelled with the specified ID does not exist, the removal of the requested node is unsuccessful and, therefore, false is returned.

        After successfully removing a vertex, the value returned by Graph.getSize() is be decremented.

        Parameters:
        id - the ID of the vertex to be removed.
        Returns:
        true if the requested vertex is successfully removed from the graph

      • setEdgeWeight

        boolean setEdgeWeight​(int id1,
                      int id2,
                      int weight)
        Sets the weight of the edge linking the two specified nodes.

        Should the graph to be implemented to be directed, the order of the IDs given as parameters for this function must be fixed. Additionally, the implementation of Vertex should be done accordingly.

        If that edge does not exist, false is returned.

        Parameters:
        id1 - the identifier of the first vertex.
        id2 - the identifier of the second vertex.
        weight - the weight to be assigned to the specified edge.
        Returns:
        true if the assignment of the weight of the requested edge is successful

      • getAllVertices

        Vertex[] getAllVertices()
        Returns an array containing all vertices in the graph. If the graph contains zero nodes, an empty array is returned.
        Returns:
        an array with all vertices of the graph
